docs.title: Welcome
docs.text:
Warning

Sculk is still in early development and may be unstable

Sculk is a CLI tool for creating Minecraft modpacks, much like Packwiz. It is aimed at modpack creators, rather than users (for users, a program such as Ferium is recommended)

docs.title: Why Sculk?
docs.text:
• Multi-source support: Sculk allows one mod to have multiple sources (e.g. Curseforge, Modrinth, and a URL). This means that you can export Modrinth and Curseforge modpacks from the same Sculk modpack.
  • Content support: Sculk supports mods, datapacks, resource packs, and shader packs - as well as any other files you want to include in your modpack (e.g. config).
  • Ease of use: Sculk is designed to be easy to use, with a simple command-line interface (with nice prompts!).
  • Import support: Sculk allows you to convert an existing Modrinth, Curseforge, or Packwiz modpack into a Sculk modpack.
  • Dependency management: Sculk automatically installs dependencies for you, and will keep track of them so that they can be removed if their dependant is.
  • [Planned] Rollback system: Sculk keeps track of changes made to the modpack, so that you can easily revert changes - because it's too easy to forget to keep your Git commits granular.
  • [Planned] Publishing support: Sculk can export to Curseforge and Modrinth modpacks, and can even publish them for you from the command line.

docs.title: How?
docs.text:
To install Sculk, first make sure you have Java 17 or greater installed, then:

  • On Linux/MacOS, run python3 <(wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/sculk-cli/sculk/main/install.py -q -O-)
  • On Windows, run Invoke-WebRequest -Uri "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/sculk-cli/sculk/main/install.py" -OutFile "install.py"; python3 .\install.py

Tip

If you'd rather install Sculk manually, download sculk.zip from the latest release. Extract it and make sure that the bin directory is in your PATH

Once Sculk is installed and on your PATH, you can follow the getting started guide. The 'How It Works' page is also recommended before you begin.

There is also documentation on specific commands and the manifest format Sculk uses, which can be found in the navbar.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
A Sculk modpack is comprised of a root manifest (manifest.sculk.json), many file manifests (such as mods/sodium.sculk.json), and other files (such as config/sodium.json).

The root manifest stores metadata about the modpack, such as its name and Minecraft version, as well as a list of manifests and files:

  • Manifests store metadata about specific file downloads. They include metadata such as the files name and its installation side. They also include the data required to download the file from either of 3 sources: Modrinth, Curseforge, or a direct URL. File manifests can include multiple sources, so that the most appropriate one can be used when exporting (i.e. use the Modrinth metadata to export to a Modrinth pack, but the Curseforge metadata to export to a Curseforge pack).
  • Files are directly stored on the file system (rather than being a manifest). The root manifest stores their path, installation side (e.g. for client-side only configs), and their SHA256 hash for integrity checking.

docs.title: Dependency Tracking
docs.text:
When you add a mod from Modrinth or Curseforge, Sculk automatically recursively adds its dependencies to the pack if they do not already exist. Sculk also tracks these dependencies so that if you remove the dependant mod in the future, the dependencies can also be removed (assuming no other mods require them). Let's use an example:

  1. You add Utility Belt to your empty Fabric modpack using sculk mr add utility-belt. This adds Utility Belt, Architectury API, JamLib, Trinkets, and Fabric API.

The dependency graph, stored at dependency-graph.sculk.json, now looks like this:

{
  "mods/trinkets.sculk.json": [
    "mods/utility-belt.sculk.json"
  ],
  "mods/fabric-api.sculk.json": [
    "mods/utility-belt.sculk.json",
    "mods/architectury-api.sculk.json",
    "mods/jamlib.sculk.json"
  ],
  "mods/architectury-api.sculk.json": [
    "mods/jamlib.sculk.json",
    "mods/utility-belt.sculk.json"
  ],
  "mods/jamlib.sculk.json": [
    "mods/utility-belt.sculk.json"
  ]
}

The graph stores a list of <dependency mod> to a list of its <dependant mods>

  1. You also add Wake Up Time, which does not add any other dependencies since they are already satisfied. It does, however, add itself to the dependency graph:
{
  "mods/trinkets.sculk.json": [
    "mods/utility-belt.sculk.json"
  ],
  "mods/fabric-api.sculk.json": [
    "mods/utility-belt.sculk.json",
    "mods/architectury-api.sculk.json",
    "mods/jamlib.sculk.json",
    "mods/wake-up-time.sculk.json"
  ],
  "mods/architectury-api.sculk.json": [
    "mods/jamlib.sculk.json",
    "mods/utility-belt.sculk.json",
    "mods/wake-up-time.sculk.json"
  ],
  "mods/jamlib.sculk.json": [
    "mods/utility-belt.sculk.json",
    "mods/wake-up-time.sculk.json"
  ]
}
  1. You decide to remove Utility Belt. This also removed Trinkets, since Trinkets has no more dependants.
  2. You also want to remove Wake Up Time. This removes JamLib, Architectury API, and Fabric API, since they also have no more dependants.

docs.title: Exporting
docs.text:
There are 3 methods for exporting/installing a Sculk modpack:

  1. Direct Install (sculk install): this method directly downloads a Sculk manifest and traverses it to download all the files for the selected side. When a manifest is encountered, it downloads the file from one of the sources that manifest specifies, and when a file is encountered it copies it over to the correct folder.
  2. Modrinth Export (sculk export mr): this method exports a Modrinth mrpack modpack. For manifests, it uses either the Modrinth or URL source (assuming the URL source is on the allowed URL list), and for files it copies them into the common, client, or server override folder in the modpack.
  3. Curseforge Export (sculk export cf): this method exports a Curseforge .zip modpack. It functions similarly to the Modrinth export, but uses the Curseforge source.

docs.title: Completion
docs.text: Generate a completion script for the specified shell.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: • sculk completion <shell>

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • <shell> (one of bash, zsh, fish): the shell to generate the completion script for.

docs.title: Init
docs.text: Initialize a new Sculk modpack.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
• sculk init (input options via prompts and have path default to .)
  • sculk init <path> (input options via prompts)
  • sculk init --name <name> --loader <loader> --minecraft-version <minecraft_version> <path>

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• <path>: the path to the modpack folder.
  • <name>: the name of the modpack.
  • <loader> (one of forge, fabric, neoforge, quilt): the mod loader to use.
  • <minecraft_version>: the Minecraft version to use.

docs.title: Install
docs.text: .Install a Sculk modpack from a URL or local directory.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
• sculk install <modpack> (install location defaults to ., side defaults to server)
  • sculk install <modpack> <path> (side defaults to server)
  • sculk install --side <side> <modpack> <path>

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• <modpack>: the URL or path to the modpack. See the guide on installing from GitHub.
  • <path>: the path to install the modpack to.
  • <side> (one of client, server): the side to install the modpack for.

docs.title: Link
docs.text: Finds Curseforge/Modrinth projects for files in the manifest.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
• sculk link <target>
  • sculk link -y <target>

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• <target> (one of modrinth, curseforge): the site to find projects from.
  • <y>, <yes>: automatically accept matches without prompting.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
• Run sculk add modrinth fabric-api
  • Run sculk link curseforge
  • You now have a Fabric API manifest with both a Modrinth and Curseforge source.

docs.title: Migrate
docs.text: Migrate a pack to the latest format version.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: • sculk migrate

docs.title: Modlist
docs.text: Generate a markdown mod list.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: • sculk modlist <file>

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • <file>: the file to write the list to.

docs.title: Refresh
docs.text: Check all hashes in the manifest and update them if needed.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
• sculk refresh
  • sculk refresh --check
  • sculk refresh --watch

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• <check>: if provided, Sculk will just check the pack without updating any bad hashes (useful for CI).
  • <watch>: if provided, Sculk will watch the file system for changes, and fresh the manifest when one is detected.

docs.title: Remove
docs.text: Remove a file or manifest.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: • sculk remove <filename>

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • <filename>: the path to the file or manifest to remove.

docs.title: Update
docs.text: Update projects from Curseforge and Modrinth.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
• sculk update (update all projects)
  • sculk update <project>

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • <project>: the path to the manifest to update

docs.title: Curseforge
docs.text: Adds a project to the manifest from Curseforge.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
• sculk add curseforge <query>
  • sculk add curseforge --skip-dependencies

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• query: the slug of a project, or a term to search.
  • skip-dependencies: whether to ignore adding dependencies.

docs.title: List
docs.text: Adds projects to the manifest from a userscript export list.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: • sculk add list <file>

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • file: the path to the list file.

docs.title: Modrinth
docs.text: Adds a project to the manifest from Modrinth.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
• sculk add modrinth <query>
  • sculk add modrinth --skip-dependencies <query>
  • sculk add modrinth --version-id <version_id>

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• query: the slug of a project, or a term to search.
  • version_id: a specific Modrinth version ID to add. If this is provided, the query will be ignored.
    • skip-dependencies: whether to ignore adding dependencies.

docs.title: URL
docs.text: Adds a project to the manifest from a direct download URL.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
• sculk add url (input options via prompts)
  • sculk add url --slug <slug> --url <url> --filename <filename> --type <type> --side <side>

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• slug: the slug of the project, used for naming the file manifest.
  • url: the download URL of the file.
  • filename: the file name.
  • type (one of mod, shaderpack, resourcepack, datapack): the type of the project.
  • side (one of both, client_only, server_only): the side the project is for.

docs.title: Curseforge
docs.text: Export a Curseforge modpack (.zip).

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: • sculk export curseforge

docs.title: Modrinth
docs.text: Export a Modrinth modpack (.mrpack).

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: • sculk export modrinth

docs.title: MultiMC
docs.text: Export a MultiMC-compatible (i.e. MultiMC, Prism, etc.) modpack (.zip).

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
• sculk export multimc
  • `sculk export multimc --pack-url
  • `sculk export multimc --pack-url --sculk-jar-location

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• pack_url: the URL (or local path) to download/update the pack from (see the installing from GitHub if you are using GitHub).
  • sculk_jar_location: the path of sculk.jar, to use for auto updating. If unspecified, Sculk will try to automatically resolve its location.

docs.title: Curseforge
docs.text: Import a Curseforge modpack (.zip).

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: • sculk import curseforge <modpack>

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • <modpack>: the path to the modpack ZIP.

docs.title: Modrinth
docs.text: Import a Modrinth modpack (.mrpack).

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: • sculk import modrinth <modpack>

docs.title: Options
docs.text: • <modpack>: the path to the modpack file.

docs.title: Checking with GitHub Actions
docs.text:
If you publish your Sculk modpack to a GitHub repository, you can use GitHub Actions to verify your hashes are correct when you push your changes.

Copy the following workflow into .github/workflows/check.yml:

name: Check

on:
  push:
  pull_request:

jobs:
  check:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    permissions:
      contents: read

    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v4
    - name: Set up JDK 17
      uses: actions/setup-java@v4
      with:
        java-version: '17'
        distribution: 'temurin'
    - name: Setup Python 3
      uses: actions/setup-python@v2
    - name: Install Sculk
      run: python3 <(wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/sculk-cli/sculk/main/install.py -q -O-)
    - name: Check hashes
      run: ~/.sculk/bin/sculk refresh --check

And add .github/workflows/check.yml to the .sculkignore file.

The workflow setups Java 17 and Python 3, then installs Sculk. It uses the sculk refresh --check command to check for the packs integrity. The workflow will fail if any hashes are invalid.

docs.title: Finding Mods Using the Userscript
docs.text:
Sculk provides a Tampermonkey userscript which can be used to add mods to a Sculk modpack from Modrinth and Curseforge. It can be found here.

Once it is installed, there are 3 buttons added to every project page on Modrinth and Curseforge:

  1. "Add to Sculk Install List": adds a project to the install list
  2. "Export Sculk Install List": exports the install list to a file
  3. "Clear Sculk Install List": clears the install list

Once the list is exported, you can use the sculk add list <path to list file> to install all the mods in the list.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
This page assumes you have read 'How It Works'

There are two ways to start a Sculk modpack:

  1. Using the sculk init command. Enter a new empty directory in the command line, and run the init command. You will be prompted for several inputs before a skeleton modpack is created.
  2. Importing an existing pack from Modrinth or Curseforge (Packwiz import support is planned in the future): run sculk import mr <path to .mrpack> or sculk import cf <path to curseforge pack .zip>. This imports all of the projects and files from the existing modpack, converting them to Sculk manifests where possible.

You can also look at the example modpack for an example of a fully functioning pack that implements all of the guides on this site.

Info

You can type to filter list prompts such as the Minecraft version prompt.

Use the sculk add mr <search query or mod slug>, sculk add cf <search query or mod slug>, or <sculk add url> commands to add mods (or shaderpacks, datapacks, etc.) to your modpack. To add files such as configs, just place the file in the correct folder and run sculk refresh.

Info

You can use the sculk link command to find Curseforge/Modrinth projects for already added projects.

Info

If you have a file which you do not want to be added when you run sculk refresh, add it to a .sculkignore file.

To test your modpack, run sculk install <path to modpack folder> in a .minecraft folder - you can add this as a pre-launch command if your launcher supports it.

Once you are familiar with the basics, you can take a look at the other guides on this site, as well as documentation for specific commands.

docs.title: Installing from GitHub
docs.text:
You can install a Sculk pack hosted on a GitHub repository using the sculk install command.

Run the command sculk install https://raw.githubusercontent.com/<user>/<repo>/<branch>, replacing <user>, <repo>, and <branch>. Sculk will automatically download all the files over HTTP.

docs.title: Using with Nix
docs.text:
Sculk provides a Nix flake which contains the package itself, as well as a function to fetch a Sculk modpack as a derivation.

Support is only provided for users using flakes.

docs.title: Installing Sculk
docs.text:
In flake.nix:

sculk = {
    url = "github:sculk-cli/sculk?dir=nix";
    inputs.nixpkgs.follows = "nixpkgs";
};

Then run nix flake update.

In configuration.nix, add Sculk as a nixpkgs overlay:

nixpkgs.overlays = [
    inputs.sculk.overlay
];

pkgs.sculk is now available.

docs.title: Using fetchSculkModpack
docs.text:
Below is an example of how to use the fetchSculkModpack function along with nix-minecraft.

services.minecraft-servers = let
  modpack = inputs.sculk.nixFunctions.fetchSculkModpack { inherit (pkgs) stdenvNoCC sculk jre_headless; } {
    url = "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Jamalam360/pack/bd19d74601963becab9eb1232d12412133132812";
    hash = "sha256-gQl2yx2V6wuF96wmHwSdEgQUHyP2zKFbe8/EPfUgbUY=";
  };
in {
  enable = true;
  eula = true;
  openFirewall = true;
  dataDir = "/var/lib/minecraft-servers";

  servers.minecraft-server = {
    enable = true;
    package = pkgs.minecraftServers.fabric-1_20_1;
    autoStart = true;
    restart = "always";
    symlinks = {
      "mods" = "${modpack}/mods";
    };
    jvmOpts = "-Xmx10G -Xms10G";
  };
};

docs.title: dependency-graph.sculk.json
docs.text: The dependency graph file is a map from dependency mod to list<dependant mods>: e.g. mods/fabric-api.sculk.json --> [mods/utility-belt.sculk.json, mods/architectury.sculk.json]

docs.title: Manifest File
docs.text: A manifest file is any file that ends with .sculk.json and is not the root manifest.

docs.title: filename
docs.text:
• description: The name of the downloaded file.
  • type: string

docs.title: side
docs.text:
• description: The side that the file should be installed on.
  • type: client_only | server_only | both

docs.title: hashes
docs.text:
• description: The hashes of the downloaded file.
  • type: object

docs.title: hashes.sha1
docs.text:
• description: The SHA1 hash of the downloaded file.
  • type: string

docs.title: hashes.sha512
docs.text:
• description: The SHA512 hash of the downloaded file.
  • type: string

docs.title: hashes.murmur2
docs.text:
• description: The Murmur2 (Curseforge variant) hash of the downloaded file.
  • type: int

docs.title: fileSize
docs.text:
• description: The size of the downloaded file, in bytes.
  • type: int

docs.title: sources
docs.text:
• description: The sources that can be used to download the file.
  • type: object

docs.title: sources.curseforge
docs.text:
• description: The Curseforge source.
  • type: object?

docs.title: sources.curseforge.projectId
docs.text:
• description: The Curseforge project ID.
  • type: int

docs.title: sources.curseforge.fileId
docs.text:
• description: The Curseforge file ID.
  • type: int

docs.title: sources.curseforge.fileUrl
docs.text:
• description: The Curseforge file download URL.
  • type: string

docs.title: sources.modrinth
docs.text:
• description: The Modrinth source.
  • type: object?

docs.title: sources.modrinth.projectId
docs.text:
• description: The Modrinth project ID.
  • type: string

docs.title: sources.modrinth.fileUrl
docs.text:
• description: The Modrinth file download URL.
  • type: string

docs.title: sources.url
docs.text:
• description: The URL source.
  • type: object?

docs.title: sources.modrinth.url
docs.text:
• description: The file download URL.
  • type: string

docs.title: formatVersion
docs.text:
• description: The format version of the modpack. [see Versioning]
  • type: string

docs.title: name
docs.text:
• description: The name of the modpack. Used in exports.
  • type: string

docs.title: version
docs.text:
• description: The version of the modpack. Used in exports.
  • type: string (semver, ideally)

docs.title: loader
docs.text:
• description: The mod loader to use and its version.
  • type: object

docs.title: loader.type
docs.text:
• description: The mod loader to use
  • type: fabric | forge | neoforge | quilt

docs.title: loader.version
docs.text:
• description: The version to use for the mod loader
  • type: string

docs.title: manifests
docs.text:
• description: The manifests included in the pack.
  • type: array

docs.title: manifests[].path
docs.text:
• description: The path to the manifest.
  • type: string (path, ends with .sculk.json and is relative to the root manifest)

docs.title: manifests[].sha256
docs.text:
• description: The SHA256 hash of the manifest file.
  • type: string

docs.title: files
docs.text:
• description: The files included in the pack.
  • type: array

docs.title: files[].path
docs.text:
• description: The path to the file.
  • type: string (path)

docs.title: files[].sha256
docs.text:
• description: The SHA256 hash of the file.
  • type: string

docs.title: files[].side
docs.text:
• description: The side that the file should be installed on.
  • type: client_only | server_only | both

docs.title: Versioning
docs.text:
The Sculk manifest is versioned such that new features can be added without breaking existing modpacks. The formatVersion key in the root manifest defines the current format version for the modpack.

Modpacks using an old format version will not work and have to be migrated using the sculk migrate command. Some migrations may take some time, as they may have to make web requests or download files.

The current latest version is 1.1.

docs.title: V1.0
docs.text: • Initial public alpha release.

docs.title: V1.1
docs.text: • Add a murmur2 field to the hashes object of file manifests.
